thainame.text: โจ๊ก

description.text: Of Chinese origin, it is a rice congee with minced chicken or pork. Mixing an egg in with the congee is optional.

thainame.text: ข้าวกั๊นจิ๊น

description.text: A dish of the Tai Yai (Shan people) of Myanmar and northern Thailand, it is rice that is mixed with pork blood and steamed inside a banana leaf. Khao kan chin is served with cucumber, onions and fried, dried chillies.[1]

thainame.text: ข้าวขาหมู

description.text: Steamed rice is served with sliced pig's trotters which has been simmered in soy sauce and five spice powder. It is always served with a sweet spicy dipping sauce, fresh bird's eye chillies and cloves of garlic on the side. Boiled egg and a clear broth on the side are optional.

thainame.href: http://www.forvo.com/word/ข้าวไข่เจียว/#th
thainame.text: ข้าวไข่เจียว

description.text: A quick snack or breakfast, it is an omelet with white rice, often eaten with chilli sauce and cucumber. The variant shown in the image is khao khai chiao songkhrueang (Thai: ข้าวไข่เจียวทรงเครื่อง) where the omelet is topped with a minced pork and vegetable stir-fry.

thainame.href: http://www.forvo.com/word/ข้าวคลุกกะปิ/#th
thainame.text: ข้าวคลุกกะปิ

description.text: Rice is fried with shrimp paste and served with sweet pork, sour mango, fried shrimp, chillies and shallots.

thainame.href: http://www.forvo.com/word/ข้าวหมกไก่/#th
thainame.text: ข้าวหมกไก่

description.text: The Thai version of a "chicken biryani". The name literally means "rice covered chicken". This Thai-Muslim dish is made by cooking rice together with the chicken curry.

thainame.text: ข้าวหมกเนื้อ

description.text: The Thai version of a "beef biryani".

thainame.href: http://www.forvo.com/word/ข้าวมันไก่/#th
thainame.text: ข้าวมันไก่

description.text: Rice steamed with garlic served with sliced chicken, chicken broth and a spicy dipping sauce.

thainame.text: ข้าวหมูกรอบ

description.text: Rice and crispy pork that is often, as here in this image, served with boiled egg and a bowl of broth. The sauce that always comes with khao mu krop is here served separately in the bowl at the top of the image.

thainame.href: http://www.forvo.com/word/ข้าวหมูกรอบหมูแดง/#th
thainame.text: ข้าวหมูกรอบหมูแดง

description.text: Slices of mu krop (crispy pork) and mu daeng (red roast pork) served on rice, and often covered with a sticky soya and/or oyster-sauce based sauce. Very often, a clear soup, boiled egg, cucumber, and spring onion is served on the side. Sliced chillies in Chinese black vinegar and dark soy sauce are provided as a condiment for this dish.

thainame.href: http://www.forvo.com/word/ข้าวหน้าเป็ด/#th
thainame.text: ข้าวหน้าเป็ด

description.text: Boiled rice with roast duck and duck broth on the side. It is served with sliced chillies in soy sauce as a condiment.

thainame.href: http://www.forvo.com/word/ข้าวเหนียว/#th
thainame.text: ข้าวเหนียว

description.text: Khao niao is traditionally eaten using only the right hand. It is the staple food of Northern and Northeastern Thais.

thainame.text: ข้าวเนื้ออบ

description.text: Rice with slices of baked beef, served with a spicy chilli dip.

thainame.text: ข้าวผัด

description.text: Fried rice in Thailand can be made with different ingredients. Customarily served with fresh lime, cucumber, spring onions and nam pla phrik (chillies in fish sauce).

thainame.href: http://www.forvo.com/word/ข้าวผัดอเมริกัน/#th
thainame.text: ข้าวผัดอเมริกัน

description.text: American fried rice is rice fried with onion, tomato, raisins and flavoured with ketchup. It is often garnished with some sausage, fried chicken and egg.

thainame.text: ข้าวผัดแกงเขียวหวาน

description.text: Rice fried with green curry.

thainame.href: http://www.forvo.com/word/ข้าวผัดกะเพราหมู/#th
thainame.text: ข้าวผัดกะเพราหมู

description.text: Rice fried with a certain variety of Thai basil called kaphrao (Ocimum tenuiflorum), sliced pork and chillies.

thainame.text: ข้าวผัดหนำเลี๊ยบ

description.text: Rice fried with nam liap, the fruit of the Canarium album, also known as "Chinese olives".

engname.text: Khao phat nam phrik long ruea

thainame.text: ข้าวผัดน้ำพริกลงเรือ

description.text: Rice fried with Nam phrik long ruea (lit. "boat journey chilli paste") and pieces of khai khem (salted duck's eggs). Fried, sliced, sweet Chinese sausage called kun chiang (Thai: กุนเชียง) are also served here with some sliced cucumber on the side.

thainame.href: http://www.forvo.com/word/ข้าวผัดน้ำพริกนรก/#th
thainame.text: ข้าวผัดน้ำพริกนรก

description.text: The name literally means "rice fried with chilli paste from hell". The rice is fried with nam phrik narok, a very spicy chilli paste made with fried catfish, grilled onion and garlic, grilled (dried) chillies, sugar, fish sauce and shrimp paste. Here it is served with mu yang (grilled pork) and nam chim chaeo, a spicy dipping sauce.

thainame.text: ข้าวต้ม

description.text: Boiled rice in a light broth, usually with minced pork, chicken or fish. It is often eaten for breakfast.

thainame.href: http://www.forvo.com/word/ข้าวต้มกุ๊ย/#th
thainame.text: ข้าวต้มกุ๊ย

description.text: Plain rice is cooked to a porridge and eaten as the staple together with a variety of side dishes.
